page.title: 02LANDSCAPE EAST OF WELLS
page.content: The area consists of undulating low hills about 30 metres ASL with rounded valleys mouled by ice and melt water but with very little surface water today. Offshore and along the northern margin of the marsh huge areas of sand are uncovered by the low tides.Material is brought by tidal currents from the sea bed and by longshore drift from ice age deposits which make up the cliffs 20 kms to the east. The salt and fresh water marshes which lie between the sands and the old shore are the natural development of the coast or mans' efforts,with drains and embankments,to improve the salt marsh for agricultural use. The chalk bedrock is covered with mixed glacial sands that benefitted from the benefitted from the soil improvement techniques developed by Thomas Coke.
